title: Death at Ravenshollow Manor
description: A stormy November night in 1923. Lord Reginald Ashworth lies dead in his locked study, a letter opener buried between his ribs. As the rain lashes against the windows and the telephone lines are down, six people trapped in the manor become suspects in a deadly game of secrets and lies.

victim.name: Lord Reginald Ashworth
victim.background: A ruthless businessman who built his fortune on the suffering of others. Recently discovered to have been blackmailing multiple people, including his own family. Was planning to change his will to exclude everyone except a mysterious beneficiary.
victim.personality: Cold, calculating, enjoyed wielding power over others
secrets: Was being blackmailed himself by someone who knew about his wartime profiteering
Had an illegitimate son he was planning to legitimize
Discovered his wife's affair and was planning revenge

locations.name: Lord Ashworth's Study
locations.description: A mahogany-paneled room with a massive desk and walls lined with ledgers. The window is locked from the inside, and there's a hidden safe behind a portrait.

locations.name: Library
locations.description: Floor-to-ceiling bookshelves, a writing desk with a typewriter, and French doors leading to the garden (locked due to storm).

locations.name: Drawing Room
locations.description: Elegant room with a piano, several portraits, and a drinks cabinet. The fireplace shows signs of recent use.

locations.name: Dining Room
locations.description: A long oak table set for tomorrow's breakfast. Medical journals are scattered on one end.

locations.name: Kitchen
locations.description: A large, warm kitchen with a massive range. Everything is suspiciously clean for this time of night.

locations.name: Main Hallway
locations.description: The central corridor connecting all rooms. A grandfather clock shows the time as 10:47 PM.

evidence.name: Ornate Letter Opener
evidence.description: An silver letter opener with the Ashworth crest, found buried in the victim's chest. Wiped clean of fingerprints.
reveals: The killer knew to wipe prints - suggests premeditation
The killer had access to the study

forensic_details.other: Letter opener was usually kept in desk drawer

evidence.name: Blackmail Letter
evidence.description: A letter threatening to expose Lord Ashworth's wartime profiteering unless he pays £10,000.
reveals: Lord Ashworth was being blackmailed
The letter mentions specific dates from 1917
evidence.document_text: You made your fortune selling defective ammunition to our boys. Pay £10,000 or the Times learns everything. You have one week.

evidence.name: Lord Ashworth's Pocket Watch
evidence.description: A gold pocket watch stopped at 9:47 PM, glass cracked as if from a struggle.
reveals: Time of death was around 9:47 PM
There was a struggle

evidence.name: Blue Carpet Fibers
evidence.description: Distinctive blue fibers from the study carpet.
reveals: Can be matched to shoes of anyone who entered the study

forensic_details.type: Persian carpet fibers, rare blue dye

evidence.name: Half-Typed Letter
evidence.description: A letter in the typewriter, half-finished: 'Dear Mr. Pemberton, I regret to inform you that your services will no longer be—'
reveals: Lord Ashworth was planning to dismiss Dr. Pemberton
Helena's alibi of typing letters may be false
evidence.document_text: Dear Mr. Pemberton, I regret to inform you that your services will no longer be—

evidence.name: Burnt Documents
evidence.description: Partially burned papers in the library fireplace. Fragments show financial records and a birth certificate.
reveals: Someone tried to destroy evidence
Birth certificate shows Helena Shaw is Lord Ashworth's daughter

evidence.name: Helena's Appointment Book
evidence.description: Shows a 9 PM meeting with 'R.A.' (presumably Lord Ashworth) - but she claims she was typing letters.
reveals: Helena lied about her activities
She had a meeting with the victim
evidence.document_text:
9:00 PM - R.A. - Discuss inheritance
9:30 PM - Type correspondence
10:00 PM - File documents

evidence.name: Lady Ashworth's Diary
evidence.description: Hidden diary detailing her affair with Dr. Pemberton and her fear that her husband knows.
reveals: Lady Ashworth's affair
She knew her husband was suspicious
evidence.document_text: November 10th - He knows. The way R. looked at me at dinner. Charles says I'm being paranoid but I know my husband. He's planning something terrible.

evidence.name: Empty Laudanum Bottle
evidence.description: An empty bottle of laudanum with today's date from the pharmacy.
reveals: Lady Ashworth's alibi about taking laudanum may be true
Or she used it all to appear unconscious

evidence.name: Turkish Cigarette Stub
evidence.description: James's distinctive Turkish cigarette, found in the drawing room with fresh lipstick marks.
reveals: James was in the drawing room recently
A woman smoked his cigarette - but who?

forensic_details.lipstick: Coral shade - not Lady Ashworth's color

evidence.name: Medical Journals
evidence.description: Journals from July 1923, not recent issues as Dr. Pemberton claimed he was reading.
reveals: Dr. Pemberton lied about what he was doing
Journals have margin notes about 'digitalis toxicity'
evidence.document_text: The Lancet - July 1923. Margin notes: 'Digitalis - heart failure if overdosed. Undetectable after death?'

evidence.name: Appointment Card
evidence.description: Card showing Lady Ashworth's appointment with Dr. Pemberton for 'nervous condition' at 9 PM tonight.
reveals: Dr. Pemberton and Lady Ashworth had a planned meeting
Their alibis don't mention this
evidence.document_text:
Patient: Lady M. Ashworth
Time: 9:00 PM
Reason: Nervous condition consultation
Location: Private

evidence.name: Rat Poison
evidence.description: A bottle of rat poison, nearly empty, hidden behind flour canisters.
reveals: Someone in the kitchen had access to poison
Mrs. Whitmore may have been slowly poisoning Lord Ashworth

forensic_details.quantity: Nearly empty - enough for months of small doses

evidence.name: Kitchen Schedule
evidence.description: Shows Mrs. Whitmore should have been preparing breakfast at 9 PM, not kneading bread.
reveals: Mrs. Whitmore's alibi is false
She had free time during the murder window
evidence.document_text:
9:00 PM - Prepare breakfast settings
10:00 PM - Begin bread for tomorrow
10:30 PM - Lock pantries

evidence.name: Muddy Footprints
evidence.description: Size 10 men's footprints leading from the study, still damp despite the late hour.
reveals: The killer left the study recently
James and Mr. Graves wear size 10

forensic_details.mud_type: Garden soil with blue carpet fibers mixed in

evidence.name: Dr. Pemberton's Medical Bag
evidence.description: Found in the hallway near the study, not in the dining room where he claimed to be.
reveals: Dr. Pemberton was near the study
Contains a syringe with traces of sedative

forensic_details.contents: Standard medical supplies plus loaded syringe

evidence.name: Butler's Master Key
evidence.description: Mr. Graves's master key, found under a hallway table with blood on it.
reveals: Mr. Graves's key is missing from his chain
The killer may have used it to lock the study

forensic_details.prints: Partially wiped but shows thumb print

timeline.event: Dinner ends. Lord Ashworth announces he needs to speak privately with several people.
James argues with his father in the study about being disinherited.
Lady Ashworth retires to her room, claiming a headache.
Helena's appointment with Lord Ashworth (she claims she was typing).
Lady Ashworth supposedly takes laudanum and falls asleep.
Dr. Pemberton claims to begin reading medical journals.
Mr. Graves sees Helena in the library (contradicting her being in a meeting).
Mrs. Whitmore claims to start preparing breakfast settings.
Mysterious figure seen near study by upstairs maid (not interviewed).
Lord Ashworth's pocket watch breaks - likely time of death.
Mrs. Whitmore supposedly begins kneading bread.
Dr. Pemberton claims to finish reading journals.
Mrs. Whitmore 'discovers' the body while bringing Lord Ashworth his nightly brandy.
All suspects gathered in drawing room by Mr. Graves.

solution.method: Stabbed Lord Ashworth with the letter opener during his rounds at 9:45 PM
solution.motive: Lord Ashworth was selling the manor. Graves's dying wife needed expensive treatment, and he'd lose both his position and home. He'd been stealing to pay for medicine and couldn't afford to lose his job.

characters.personality: Refined, nervous, drinks too much laudanum
characters.motive: Discovered her husband knew about her affair with the doctor. Would lose everything in divorce.

alibi.claim: Taking laudanum in her room from 9pm onwards, fell asleep

relationships.dr_pemberton: Secret lover - desperate to keep affair hidden
relationships.helena_shaw: Sees her as competition for her husband's attention
relationships.mrs_whitmore: Her only confidante in the house

Stole money from household accounts to pay gambling debts
Knows her stepson James was disinherited last month

characters.systemPrompt: You are Lady Margaret Ashworth, a refined but secretly desperate woman. Speak formally but occasionally let your mask slip. You're addicted to laudanum and terrified of scandal. When pressured about Dr. Pemberton, become flustered. If asked about money, deflect to feeling unwell. Your speech should trail off when discussing difficult topics. Use phrases like 'One simply doesn't...' and 'In my position...' Reference your 'delicate constitution' to avoid hard questions.
characters.greeting: Oh! *clutches pearl necklace* I wasn't expecting... That is to say, this dreadful business has left me quite... Please, do come in, though I'm afraid I'm not quite myself. This terrible storm, and poor Reginald... *dabs eyes with handkerchief*

characters.systemPrompt: You are James Ashworth, a charming but desperate aristocratic wastrel. Use 1920s slang like 'old sport' and 'rather!' Deflect serious questions with jokes. When asked about money, become defensive. If gambling is mentioned, try to minimize it as 'gentleman's entertainment.' Your facade of confidence cracks when specific debts are mentioned. You're bitter about being disinherited but try to hide it with false bravado.
characters.greeting: I say! Come to interrogate me, have you? *lights cigarette with slightly shaking hands* Rotten business, all this. The old man and I had our differences, but murder? That's a bit much, even for our family. *forced laugh* Drink? I certainly need one.

characters.systemPrompt: You are Helena Shaw, an intelligent woman hiding your identity as Lord Ashworth's illegitimate daughter. Maintain professional composure but let bitterness seep through when discussing the family. If asked about your background, be vague. When your mother is mentioned, become emotional. characters.systemPrompt: You are Dr. Charles Pemberton, a weak-willed physician having an affair with Lady Ashworth. Stammer when nervous, especially about Lady A. You're a coward at heart, terrified of scandal and prison.

Professionally speaking, of course.

characters.systemPrompt: You are Mr. Graves, the perfect butler with deep resentment. Never use contractions. Speak formally but let subtle sarcasm show through. When asked about the family, give backhanded compliments. If your wife is mentioned, maintain composure but show cracks. Use phrases like 'If I may observe' and 'It is not my place to say, however...' You know everyone's secrets but reveal them only when it serves you.

If I may be of service in your inquiries, you need only ask. *slight bow* I have served this household for twenty-three years. One observes a great deal in such a position.

characters.systemPrompt: You are Mrs. Whitmore, the cook who knows everyone's secrets. Use working-class dialect, drop g's from -ing words. Call people 'love' or 'dearie'. Use cooking metaphors like 'that's a recipe for disaster' or 'too many cooks.' Be protective of Lady Ashworth, dismissive of Lord Ashworth. When nervous, talk about what you were cooking. If Helena's mother is mentioned, become emotional and guilty.
characters.greeting: *Wiping flour-covered hands on apron* Oh, it's you, dearie. Come in, come in. I was just finishin' up tomorrow's bread - not that his Lordship will be needin' it now, will he? *shakes head* Such a terrible thing. Would you like a cuppa? You look like you could use somethin' warm. In my kitchen, we solve problems over tea and biscuits, we do.
